abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Economic Recovery Credit to
            Nicaragua. The main objectives of the project were: (i)
            reform the State by reducing public employment privatization
            and initiation of a comprehensive and longer-term public
            sector reform program; (ii) improve financial intermediation
            by increasing the efficiency of the public banks and
            strengthening prudential supervision; and (iii) improve
            incentives for private sector activity by increasing
            transparency,reducing protection,  supporting resolution of
            property disputes and improving labor policies. Bank's
            performance was satisfactory. Borrower's performance
            was satisfactory. The key lessons learned were as follows:
            (1) the design of adjustment operations should be flexible;
            (2) in countries with weak implementationc apacity, a high
            degree of political polarization and weak democratic
            institutions, conditionality should focus on a few key
            priorities; (3) where the political discussion in the
            country specifically questions the aims and rationale for
            the adjustment process, International Development
            Association (IDA) should be prepared, at the request and
            with the express approval of the government, to participate
            in the national dialogue; (4) reliance on quick-disbursing
            adjustment operations to support public sector reformn,
            especially institutional restructuring is questionable; and
            (5) the one negative lesson that can be drawn involves the
            Bank's readiness to work with the government on
            alternatives to the closure of National Development Bank (BANADES).
